section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: This handsâ€‘on section guides learners through creating variables, understanding Python's core data types, manipulating collections, and performing type conversions. Each lesson includes practical exercises to reinforce concepts.
learning_objectives: Students will be able to declare and assign variables using appropriate naming conventions.
Students will be able to differentiate between mutable and immutable data types.
Students will be able to perform type conversion and use built-in functions to inspect data types.
Students will be able to apply variables and data types in practical coding exercises.

lessons.lesson_title: Creating and Naming Variables in Python
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables with valid identifiers and assign values of various types.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Write a script that declares at least five variables of different types (int, float, string, bool, list). Use meaningful names and print each variable.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to identify and use Python's primitive data types correctly.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables for each primitive type, perform an operation appropriate to the type (e.g., add two integers, concatenate two strings), and print the results with type() output.

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Collections: Lists, Tuples, and Dictionaries
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create, access, and modify list, tuple, and dictionary structures.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Construct a list of five numbers, a tuple of three strings, and a dictionary mapping three names to ages. Perform at least two modifications on the list, attempt to modify the tuple (observe error), and update one dictionary entry. Print all structures after changes.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert between data types and use built-in functions to inspect variable types.

exercises.exercise_instructions: Given a string '123', convert it to int and add 10. Convert a float 9.87 to string and concatenate with ' dollars'. Create a list from a tuple of characters and verify its type. Use isinstance() to check if a variable is a list.
